entry.definition: Processed data that is organized, meaningful, and useful, including documents, audio, images, and video.
Database relationship in which one instance of entity A is associated with one instance of entity B.

Database relationship in which one instance of entity A can correspond to many instances of entity B, but an instance of B can correspond to only one A , for example, a grade has many students, but each student is in only one grade.
Is available when the decision-maker needs it.
A named field in a database, also a column.
Database issue that arises when multiple people have shared access to the same database
Gives more value than it costs to produce.
A window that provides areas for entering or changing data in a database.
A collection of related records stored on a storage medium such as a hard disk, CD, or DVD.
The quality of the data, i.e., the quantity of errors.
Finding patterns and relationship s among data.
Rules and standards that define how a database organizes data.
The kind of data a field can contain, such as text (alphanumeric), numeric, date
A huge database that stores and manages the data required to analyze historical and current transactions.
Application software that allows users to create, access, and manage a database (i.e., Microsoft Access).

A collection of data organized in a manner that allows access, retrieval, and use of that data, or a large, integrated collection of data organized to support access which models some aspects of reality.
That part of the Web which is not indexed by search engines because its pages are generated in response to queries and are not linked to other pages.
A unique identifier for each field in a database.
The maximum number of characters a field can contain.
An "atomic" unit of data.
A field in a relational database that matches the primary key of another table.
In SQL, associates records from two tables so information can be retrieved.
A listing of activities that change the contents of the database.
A type of database relationship in which multiple matches are possible between items A and B and between B and A.
A process of organizing a database to remove ambiguous relationships between data and minimize data redundancy.
Stores data in objects, items that contain data, and actions that read or process that data
Arranged to suit the needs and requirements of the decision maker.
In a relational database, a column or set of columns that uniquely identifies each record in a field.
In SQL, specifies a subset of columns from which information will be retrieved
Simple, English-like statements that allow users to specify the data to display, print, or store.
A request for specific data from the database.
A collection of related fields.
Uses logs and/or backups to restore a destroyed or damaged database.
A database that stores data in tables that consist of rows and columns.
A connection within the data.
In SQL, retrieves only records matching particular criteria.
A query language that allows users to manage, update, and retrieve data, using special keywords and rules that users include in SQL statements.
That part of the Web which is indexed by search engines.
A collection of related records.
Has a deadline or time period suited to its use.
A row in a database.
Has meaning to the person who receives it.
The process of comparing data with a set of rules or values to find out if the data is correct.
Can be proven as correct or incorrect.
Basic properties of a database management system which allow safe sharing of information: Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, and Durability.
Pieces of information, including text, numbers, images, audio, and video.
A retrieval system using Boolean operators (AND, OR, NOT) which can be accurate and efficient, but sometimes returns nonexistent relationships.
A phrase coined after World War II to describe the challenges resulting from a rapid increase in scientific progress and scientific publications.
A retrieval system which assigns each returned documents a relevance ranking and places the most relevant first.t

In the context of an IR system, consists mainly of determining which documents of a collection contain the keywords in the user query which, most frequently, is not enough to satisfy the user information need.

Deals with the representation, storage, organization of, and access to information items. The representation and organization of the information items should provide the user with easy access to the information in which he is interested.
Search type seeking documents "about this."
Search type concerned with locating an item known to exist
Conceived by Vannevar Bush and foreshadowing development of hypertext and information retrieval.
The fraction of results retrieved by the search which are relevant. A measure of the search's success.
A type of search in which a static query is matched against newly-updated documents. Example: filter on incoming email.
The fraction of relevant results which were returned by the search, out of all relevant results. A measure of the search's success.
A measure of the effectiveness of the results returned by a search.
